**Youngest Person to Reach South Pole Solo: Scott Sears Completes Epic Trek**

Scott Sears, a 27-year-old lieutenant in the First Battalion Royal Gurkha Rifles, has become the youngest person to reach the South Pole solo, completing a 702-mile trek across the Antarctic plateau in just 38 days. Sears, brother-in-law of tennis star Andy Murray, achieved the feat on Christmas Day, more than 12 days ahead of schedule.

The journey was not without its challenges, with Sears facing 150mph winds, temperatures of -50c, and treacherous crevasses. He was not roped up to a teammate, making it a solo effort, and used skis to cross the ice instead. Despite feeling exhausted and hitting a wall with just 38km to go, Sears persevered, fueled by juice, biltong, chocolate, and music on his iPod.

Sears' journey was in support of the Gurkha Welfare Trust, raising over £33,500 to rebuild schools in Gorkha, Nepal, which were destroyed in the 2015 earthquake. The trek was also a personal challenge, with Sears having played tennis on the international circuit before joining the Army.

After reaching the South Pole, Sears described the experience as "overwhelming" and said he was looking forward to a shower and some food. His achievement has been congratulated by Andy Murray's mother, Judy Murray, who tweeted: "Well done Scott Sears - youngest person to reach the South Pole on a solo mission. Got there on Christmas Day..."

Sears is expected to take a few weeks to process the experience, having spent nearly six weeks alone in a tent. His achievement is pending confirmation from the Guinness Book of Records, but it is clear that Scott Sears has made history as the youngest person to reach the South Pole solo.assistant

The much-assailed decision was one made by owner Russell Brice, who had grown fearful of a 900-foot-wide overhang of glacial ice set directly above the main route on the mountain's Nepal side, an overhang that his members were directly under for as long as an hour while traversing the route. As Krakauer writes, the "wedge of ice the size of a Beverly Hills mansion" that broke free and caused last week's avalanche came from "that same ice bulge" and killed 16 Sherpas. As for the outsize dangers Sherpas face, some standout points: Between 1921 and 1996, the mountain's death ratio was a treacherous one death for every four completed ascents. Between 1997 and present, the death ratio was one for every 60. Among the reasons it's gotten safer: Climbers tend to pack and use more bottled oxygen, and some take the robust steroid dexamethasone once they hit 22,000 feet, which pares down the risk of developing the often fatal high-altitude cerebral edema and high-altitude pulmonary edema. Sherpas typically have less of the former and none of the latter (and are, of course, the ones lugging those extra oxygen bottles up the mountain). Krakauer points to an Outside piece that shares the professions with a lower calculated fatality rate than that of Sherpas: US soldiers stationed in Iraq between 2003 and 2007, miners, and commercial fishermen.
